target: The MFK Flagship is charging its MV drive. If you cannot destroy it before this time, it will escape! Nothing, not even destroying its engines, will stop this timer.
The MFK Flagship is charging its MV drive. If you cannot destroy it before this time, it will escape! Nothing, not even destroying its engines, will stop this timer.
The MFK Flagship is charging its MV drive. If you cannot destroy it before this time, it will escape! Nothing, not even destroying its engines, will stop this timer.
The MFK Flagship is charging its MV drive. If you cannot destroy it before this time, it will escape! Nothing, not even destroying its engines, will stop this timer.

The Flagship trembles. It has already sustained immense damage, but it holds together. A teleporter signature is registered, and it becomes clear the Rebels are playing dirty. They must have had a few Cognitives lying around after their raid, because several hostile entities are detected aboard!

The Flagship trembles. It has already sustained immense damage, but it holds together. A teleporter signature is registered, and it becomes clear the Rebels are playing dirty. They must have had a few Cognitives lying around after their raid, because several hostile entities are detected aboard!
It appears this ship is also equipped with an advanced AI system. Now that the crew is dead, it has taken control! You sense oxygen levels dropping on the Flagship as well...

As you pursue the Flagship, you know this is your last chance to prepare whatever you might need before the battle. This will be it, there's no going back once you've caught up to them. Now would be a good time to check your mission report one last time.
The Flagship jumps away, escaping from you. You've failed... and now the future of the Federation across all realities look bleak. This is a crushing defeat, and your mission is lost.
You've done all you can. Now, it's time to fight this Flagship.

You chase down Vance as fast as possible. You manage to catch up to his titan of a ship, similar in build to the Rebel Flagship, but armed with an even stronger arsenal of artillery and sporting an MFK paint job.

You didn't come this far to give up now. There's nothing left to do but destroy this ship. Fail, and the Federation is doomed, succeed and save this reality forever. The stakes are high, but you don't have time to think about them as you get ready to fight.
(Nights) Nights seems to have something to say to Vance.

You chase down Vance as fast as possible. You manage to catch up to his titan of a ship, similar in build to the Rebel Flagship, but armed with an even stronger arsenal of artillery and sporting an MFK paint job.

You didn't come this far to give up now. There's nothing left to do but destroy this ship. Fail, and the Federation is doomed, succeed and save this reality forever. The stakes are high, but you don't have time to think about them as you get ready to fight.
(Nights) Nights seems to have something say to Vance.

You chase down Vance as fast as possible. You manage to catch up to his titan of a ship, similar in build to the Rebel Flagship, but armed with an even stronger arsenal of artillery and sporting an MFK paint job.

You didn't come this far to give up now. There's nothing left to do but destroy this ship. Fail, and the Federation is doomed, succeed and save this reality forever. The stakes are high, but you don't have time to think about them as you get ready to fight.
(Nights) Nights seems to have something to say to Vance.

You chase down Vance as fast as possible. You manage to catch up to his titan of a ship, similar in build to the Rebel Flagship, but armed with an even stronger arsenal of artillery and sporting an MFK paint job.

You didn't come this far to give up now. There's nothing left to do but destroy this ship. Fail, and the Federation is doomed, succeed and save this reality forever. The stakes are high, but you don't have time to think about them as you get ready to fight.
(Nights) Nights seems to have something say to Vance.
Vance pauses, and appears on the vid screen. Nights scrolls up closer, taking another swig of his beer. "Ssssay... what wassss your name again?"
Vance grunts and scowls. "Admiral Vance Wentworth. What's it to you, slime pinata?"
Nights chuckles and takes another sip. "Heheh... Admiral Vance Wentworth, huh? More like... Wentworthlessssss! HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAH!"

Through Night's intoxicated laughter and hiccuping you can hear Vance growling, as his eye twitches in annoyance. At last, you've found validation for keeping this slimey asshole on your ship. Too bad you can't delay the inevitable any longer - it's time for a showdown!

Vance pauses, and appears on the vid screen. Tully steps foward, arms crossed behind his back. "Wentworth. Please, listen to me, not as an adversary, but as your old friend. Don't do this. Think of what you're doing, is all of this really worth it? You'll kill trillions of people and for what? To settle some petty score? You've built an empire that can compete with the Federation - why can't you just be satisfied with that?"

Vance's glare softens, but the determined look on his face doesn't falter. "This is well beyond simple revenge, Brodric. Have you never wondered why we still carry the title of Rebellion? Because it keeps our ideals and our mission true to the heart of every man who marches under our banner. To simply co-exist with the Federation is to willingly allow not only trillions but a near infinite pool of people continue to suffer."

"This multiverse will only know peace when the Federation has finally been dissolved and a new, glorious civilization can be built where the barbaric xeno-lifeforms can continue their malpractices in their own private suffering while humanity is allowed to prosper as we were always destined to do. The people of Universe 0 had their chance, but they have failed. It takes a person of diamond will to be able to commit to the lesser evil. I do not want to fight you, Brodric, but don't think our history will stop me from fulfilling my purpose."
With that, Vance ends the call immediately and his ship goes back to charging its MV Drive. Tully looks defeated, but you don't have time to contemplate. It's time for one final showdown!

As you approach the Flagship's artilleries lock onto you, preparing to blast you into oblivion. Before they can discharge however, Jerry quickly hails the ship, using confidential Rebel access codes. You wait for the response...
Though the Flagship never stops running, onto your bridge teleports the formidable figure from before. Vance has arrived. He takes a few steps towards you, glancing at Jerry in confusion.
"The Federation has fallen on hard times, if you should feel it necessary to kidnap my nephew and use him as bait to stop me from achieving inter-reality peace!"

Vance chuckles. "And what, he just willingly joined your crew? Don't be ridiculous. My nephew's loyalty to the Rebellion is unmatc-" Vance is cut off by Jerry. "They're telling the truth, uncle! I'm tired of the Rebellion. What are we even fighting for? You can't possibly rule a single reality, let alone an infinite number of them! Are you really going to outcast the dozen other sapient species? Your plan makes no sense!"

You can see Vance's eyes starting to narrow. "You stupid boy. You're just like your mother, aren't you. Blinded by false morality, unable to progress because you're too busy trying to drag the simple, ignorant creatures that should be serving us out of the primordial ooze they belong in! Yes, my plans sound grand, and that's because they are! But it takes a man of commitment and courage to accomplish that which I have set out to do. I'll be damned if anyone, family or not, keeps me from the greatness that awaits an existence under my rule."

Jerry stutters, unsure of how to react to this insult. Vance makes a simple gesture with his hand, as if to shoo him away. "I advise you all to make whatever futile preparations you need. I shall return to my ship, and I will not let any further interruptions impede me." Vance presses a button on his belt, and teleports back off to the Flagship in the distance.

Jerry collapses to his knees, shocked and speechless as how easily he was betrayed. "I should have known..." Jerry chokes up a sob, and holds his head in his hands while tears form puddles on the ground.
Jerry sits in the corner, crying. The Flagship approaches, weapons charging. You want to console him, but you have to get going.

Suddenly, Jerry gets back up to his feet, wiping away the tears. "Well, there's only one thing left to do now." He draws out a massive Gatling gun. You aren't sure where he got it from, but you don't have the time to question it.
With Jerry armed and ready, it looks like there's nothing left to do but fight!
Before you can proceed on to the Flagship, Jerry pauses, and walks out of the room.
You have no idea where Jerry is going, but you follow him.
Jerry enters the room where the Equinoid is sleeping...
You have no idea what Jerry is doing, and watch in confusion.
Then, Jerry proceeds to mount the pony! "Alright. Now I'm ready."
Before you can proceed on to the Flagship, Jerry pauses, and walks out of the room.
You have no idea where Jerry is going, but you follow him.
Jerry enters the room where the Equinoid is sleeping...
You have no idea what Jerry is doing, and watch in confusion.
Then, Jerry proceeds to mount the pony! "Alright. Now I'm ready."
You watch in triumphant jubilation as the Flagship explodes. You've won this battle!

As the MFK Flagship is destroyed, and Vance with it, you know your mission has been a success. The Rebellion will struggle to recover without their leader, but this won't be their death. You retrieve the nearby Paragon from the wreckage, and bring it back to your ship. Knowing there is little time left to lose before the fleet catches up, you take one last look at your crew. To detonate this bomb means the collapse of the Multiverse, and MV drives will simply cease to function. This will mean an end to the war... but it'll kill you and your crew, as well as strand billions of people from around the Multiverse. The choice is yours, captain. How does this end?
Detonate the Paragon; end this war.

You know what you have to do. This war must end, no matter the cost. You've been given this chance, and you won't pass it up. Your crew understands, they signed up to this knowing very well they might die. You say your last goodbyes, and activate the bomb...
Destroy the Paragon; save your crew and your fellow travelers.

This isn't your choice to make. You can't decide the fate of the entire Multiverse. You lift the Paragon, then bring it hard down onto the metal floor, smashing the seemingly invulnerable piece of tech into a million pieces. This war might never end, but if it does, it won't be because of the actions of one person.
You look around at your crew, who are standing, waiting for your verdict.
Ask the Beacon Eater about this.
Ask Tintan and Rig about this.
Ask the Orchid children what to do.

"We've come far, yeah? To think, not that long ago I was just working on a simple murder case, and I thought that was the most excitement I'd see in my whole life! Now look at us! I must say, it would be a terrible shame for my legacy to end like this, but whatever you choose, I'm onboard."

"To think, I was worried about a silly civil war when such greater things were happening behind my back. How could I go back to the Federation now that I know it's all for naught? Vance, my oldest friend, is gone. I should have remorse, but he was gone long before this conflict. Don't let me influence your decision here, I haven't got a single right to sway your mind. You're the Admiral now, captain."

"Arg lad, it's been fun serving you. End of the day, don't matter much if I was built by Rebels or not when I got to be a part of your crew, matey. It'd be a mighty shame for the pirate king to die like this, but only because it's one hell of a story I could never tell!"

Jerry looks down at his feet. "I... I think it's a good thing my uncle is gone. Not to say I hated him, but for the good of the Multiverse it's only best. I suppose this makes me the hero Vance always wanted me to be, just not in the way he expected. Savior of the Multiverse is a pretty good title! I'm glad I met you, captain. I'll stick with you to the end, whether that's today, tomorrow, or the end of time itself."

"That bastard Vance finally got what's coming to him, and I am damn glad I was aboard the ship that did it. Maybe the Federation isn't so bad after all, eh? Hah, that's a lie, but you're alright kid. Blowing up myself along with the rest of time and space sounds like a pretty fitting end to my story. I've served my purpose. Don't let me hold you back from pulling the trigger."

"It is [untraditional] for an Engi to feel emotions. It would seem my -logical- receptors have been clogged by most unusually pleasurable feelings in your company. This is not the mission I signed up for. But I do not regret it. I must [remind] you however, that my people still need me. My absence would cause -disastrous- consequences. But so would the continuation of the war. A troubling dillema. Most troubling."

"Hahahah! I knew thhhere ain't no shit like immortal demigod aliens. We sure put the fear of science in thhhhose narcissists. I'll be highly disappointed if you flick thhhat switch and I don't get to rub my victory in thhhat bitch Nerva's stupid little face. Hah!... Erm. Sorry. You're alright kid. I expected worse when we first met. Don't let it go to your head hearing it coming from me- thhhough I wouldn't blame you if it did."

"Pur too look-loo kik pik ripple steep." You have no idea what this means, but the sentiment behind it is not lost when OOJ shapes himself into a large heart. You give the giant blob a hug as he jiggles in your arms.

Nights scowls at you, but on his face you can see the faintest line of a smile you've ever seen in him outside of when he's being smug. "For the record, I ssstill hate you. But compared to everyone I hate, I hate you sssslightly lessss than the ressst. Anywayssss, thisss sssure hasss been a real sssshitty trip. If you're tellin' me I gotta blow myssself up after all of thisss, I'm gonna ssstrangle you." Knowing Nights, this is likely the closest thing anyone will ever come to for being his friend. Hopefully he isn't being serious about strangling you though.

"Beat being king, the name Ssslocknog isss going down in hissstory as ssssavior of the universssse! Hehehe. Wait, if we blow that bomb, no one will know about thisss, will they? Ehhh, ssscrew thossse guysss. If you want my sssay, I sssay blow it. I got nothin' to go back to anywayssss."

"I... I don't know what to think mate. All thisss time I thought I wasss some hot ssshot renegade hunting the biggessst game in the Multiversssse... and all thisss time I've jussst been an insssignificant ssspeck in the grand ssscheme of two different massster plansss. I feel like I'm having a moment of introssspection and I HATE it. Pleassse, don't let me live to sssee myssself become a good perssson. The Multiversssse sssucksss anywaysss. That bomb'll do only good."

Alkram grunts, pretending to be indifferent to the situation. "When we first met, the most important thing on my mind was overthrowing Tyrdeo. Yet, now that seems so insignificant... I'm a soldier, not a speaker. Lemme put my words as blunt as possible for you. Only way my people or ANY people are ever gonna learn, is when we stop relying on other people to fix our problems. This whole Multiversal War thing isn't helping anyone when the Federation, Rebellion, Coalition, or god knows who else keeps intervening and 'fixing' everything. I implore you to blow that bomb and put things the way they were before for the sake of everyone."

"Oh sweet heavens I feel faint. Is it true? We're alive? Remarkable. You're the first person not on my payroll to stand at my side while facing such adversity. I cannot thank you for all you've done for me. It feels out of place for silly old me to have any say in this... but I'd like to keep living. And I'm sure you would too. Heh... What do you think happens if we die to that thing? Are we gone for good? Oh I don't want to think about it."

"Good work chap, this is truly a spectacular moment and I couldn't think of any better way to spend it than sipping tea at the end of time. You do intend to blow the bomb, yes? Don't worry about me, the Free Mantis haven't relied on my support for years. They'll be scared, yes, but they'll make do. No more Multiverse means no more Rebels, and maybe things will finally settle down for once. My days were numbered anyways. A Mantis can only live so long."

Kazaaak seems uncertain of what to say. "For first time in long time, I am not knowing what to say. You are greater warrior than I ever was. But think, if we do not detonate Paragon and return home, we could achieve so much more! We could be greatest heroes in all of time! How could you pass up this chance?"

Even in the face of this great triumph, Ariadne remains stoic, save for a faint smirk on her face. "When I offered my services to you captain, I didn't expect you to drag me across the Multiverse into the pit of demigods to overthrow the Rebellion. But - it's been an honor. However, my initial mission is not complete. The Theocracy has not yet been defeated. I'm afraid that bomb of yours will do little to stop the Elders. I understand this is not my call to make, but I hope you have considered the weight of this decision.

"I feel as though I have served a purpose far greater than the one I set out to. You are truly the most remarkable, accomplished captain I have ever had the honor of meeting. You remind me of someone else I met long ago, another Federation captain.. But even they couldn't come close to this! But, would the destruction of the Multiverse be worth it? Think of the wonders that this technology could accomplish. It's much the same situation as my people - there will be chaos in the beginning, but I'm certain things must settle eventually. No war can truly last forever!"

"To think, I merely joined your vessel as a trial to judge you foreigners. I think it is safe to say you have passed that test, and with flying colors. I wish I had the same fervor, to go jumping across the Multiverse just to save reality. This Multiverse tech has been the ruin of many civilizations, but it has also been the birth and savior of so many more. Had you asked me any other day, I would say to detonate that bomb in an instant. But now, I can only wonder if it's best left unused..."

"This whole journey I've felt drunker than I ever did back on Sky-Drifter. It's been one hell of a trip. But hah, I can drink to this victory!" Tuco pulls out a remarkably still intact bottle of booze and downs it in seconds. "My glory days are long since over. The Multiverse doesn't need me, and frankly no one needs the Multiverse either. But if we do live past this day, I'd love to share another drink with ya, pal."

"Sparing words, difficulty communication. Symbolic gestures appropriate of more timing." The Beacon Eater retracts his mighty spikes for the first time since you met and reaches over to give you a hug. You didn't know Lanius could even do that. You prod further but it seems the Beacon Eater has nothing to say about the Paragon. For a creature that's been alive longer than the Obelisk Empire itself, it's not surprising he cares little about his own mortality anymore.

"From ancient ruins I heard mention of Paragon. But never in even dreams was I thinking I find it! If I am Anointed, then you are divine beyond doubt!" The Anointed bows to you. "For centuries my people revere Obelisk as gods, but now I am knowing of their true menace. I could not thinking any better end to their empire than the destruction of Multiverse."

"Oh grandfather Aneidio, if only thou could witness me now! Y-you. You are not worthy of a title. You have ascended past such mortal things. You have but completed in such short time what the legacy of all 16 Reapers could never. What are you? I dare not insult you with conjecture. But if you should accept my humblest opinion, then hark and listen. This Paragon, oh foul creation, is a tool of the Obelisk. An antithesis to their power yes, but of their making. Should it not seem to you most cruel after all of this to give them their way and let it be their invention that divide reality? The Obelisk will fall, but the Multiverse is a fact of our existence. Would it not be sorrowful to deprive reality of such a beautiful thing, to defile nature once again with the patent of cruel gods? Think these thoughts I ask of you, but do not let me be the one to stop you."

You find Vortigon is not with the rest of the crew, rather he has crumpled into a ball in the corner of the ship. "Oh you, Almighty Slayer of the Infernal Cube Demons, Saviour of the Multiverse, and Grand Lord of Being Above Average, everything I have ever known is a lie. I have SEEN the Ember spirits with my own eyes and I have killed them with my hands. How could a god bleed? Divinity is a lie. I cannot live with myself. I have led so many men and women astray, I have poisoned the masses with tainted lies. Yes, I believed them too, but if fate was not the one that put me there, then it was my own hubris. I ask you one final favor. I do not care what you do with the Paragon, it's far beyond my worries. But if we live past this day, take mercy on me and see to it I never return to my home. Cast me into the abyss before you sentence me to looking into the eyes of my victims once more."

"Thissss isssn't quite what I expected when I joined your crew. But hey, if there wasss any doubt about a galactic hero, an interdimenssssional hero sssure asss hell doesssn't pay taxesss! Oh, and uh... thanksss for not ssstabbing me in the back, like everyone elssse hassss. Now, assssuming we live, do you think I could ssstart ssselling Paragon merchandise? I could immortalize your image forever! But if you don't mind, I'd really like to go home. I have ssso many thingsss I need to fix, and if our journey endsss here, I'll never get the chance."

Sylvan puts a tentacle on your shoulder. "Ssstranger... in the many yearssss I've lived in thisss wild Multiverssse, I've ssseen about all there isss to ssssee. Or at leassst, ssso I thought, until I met you. The moment I firssst sssaw you, I knew you were going to be ssssomething. Ssso many runsss, eh? Feelsss like agessss, but to you it could have just been hourssss. Oh look at me rambling. Don't worry about me ssstranger. There'ssss an endlessss amount of me'sssss, and regardless of what happensss with that Paragon, we'll ssssee each other again." Sylvan winks at you and slithers away.
The Queen lets out a soft pur and nudges you with her head. You aren't sure if she can comprehend the full scope of what's happening, but it's a heartfelt gesture nonetheless.

"Your heroics are unlike any other, captain. That fateful day we met, where you promised I would be a hero of the Federation, I did not expect this, and suspect you didn't either! My legend has been told, but it lacks an end. I've come to terms now with the truth. My people are gone. Maybe it's time I join them in the great beyond, if it's even real. If you choose to activate the bomb, well, I'd be content with that ending."

Tintan and Rig hobble over. "We cannot lie, it was hell like this in the beginning. But in this troubling journey we've come to terms with our situation. Forevermore we shall be known as Rintan." Rig's stomach rumbles. "What? Tinrig? That's stupid! God damn it. We're working on it. But our point was this; thank you. We weren't grateful at first, but now we realized you saved us. Though, we must ask one selfish thing. It would be a shame for this revelation to go to waste. Are you sure the Paragon would solve everything?"

"You have shown me something I didn't expect to find. Hope. My life has been nothing but misery for the last 7 years. I was so close to ending it all. I owe you everything I have. But I cannot help but think that this Paragon is the solution to something far greater than any of us. Those Slugs, the damn bastards responsible for my suffering, are just one of many chaotic bad actors in this universe. They shouldn't have access to this tech. No one should."

"In journey, I have seen both sides of technology. Good, bad. You undoubtedly are good. You fight for justice, even if actions sometimes questionable. Obelisk, purest form of technological corruption. This Paragon, it is fascinatingly grey. Most evilest of weapons, yet also only thing capable of ending technological evils! Glad I am not in your shoes, the decision ahead is incomprehensible in its difficulty. I am just glad I gave you second chance."

"I have so little to say except... thank you. Thank you for giving me a second chance. Before we met I was nothing but a traitor, despised by my people and kept around only for my usefulness. While I may never be able to make it up to those I have betrayed, at least I have been given the chance to redeem myself through this journey."

"You've come so far - I'm impressed! For a mortal you're surprisingly resilient. But I implore you not to forget the mission. The Paragon must be detonated for the Obelisk to truly be defeated. I understand the sacrifice that must be made here, and trust me I don't look forward to it either. But our lives are just a drop in the ocean of those ruined by the Obelisk, Rebels, and even the Federation with the Multiverse tech in their hands."

The shockwave of the bomb spreads further outwards, first consuming your ship, then the entire Obelisk Homeworlds, erasing every last Obelisk and Vance's entire fleet. Around the Multiverse, billions of MV drives ceased functioning, much to the confusion of everyone. Inevitably, the Federations and Rebellions of many realities were able to work out a truce, knowing the lopsided balances of power would only spell the end for them both. Though your sacrifice will never be known, you've put an end to the unending war, and restored every reality back to the way they were before.

With the Paragon destroyed, you return to the Obelisk Homeworlds. The MFK Fleet awaits you, but when you show them the wreckage of their Flagship, they stand down. Even afterwards, the tales of your victory are spoken around the Multiverse. It seems your victory has earned you more than just another day to live - you'll forever be immortalized as the single ship that stopped the entire Rebellion. Without the original Vance, the many Rebellions of each reality struggled to gain leadership, and inevitably it spelled doom for the Rebellion. Their society collapsed, and the Federation quickly retook as many realities as they could. Though the conflict will inevitably continue for an eternity, at least things have calmed down at last.
